Content-type: text/plain;
	charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Ken-

I watched this keynote and greatly enjoyed it. Thanks for posting =
it.

I had a few thoughts that I think could improve future versions of you=
r
argument. I know you are interested in constantly optimizing these pitche=
s,
so here are my thoughts, whatever they are worth.
1. synthetic solar pan=
els are much more efficient than photosynthesis. so it
seems odd to use tha=
t as an example of something nature dominates us on.
there are so many exam=
ples where we don't compare at all to natural designs,
that you might raise=
 fewer red flags by going with an undebatable one.
2. we know a lot about c=
ancer and I think we will solve it soon (~20-40
years). I would say that is=
 more like the moon mission. we could solve it in
less than 20 years if we =
dedicated an inordinate amount of resources to it.
I think you do better to=
 pick things like levitation, time-travel, or
something in between, because=
 in that case I cannot bring to mind the steps
that need to be taken to get=
 there, which is exactly your point. with
cancer, many researchers will tel=
l you that we do know a ton of things that
need to be done, and it is just =
a matter of doing them (and building the
technology to allow them to scale)=
.
3. the mission to the moon wasn't one stepping stone away, but many. your=

argument works, but should be "a handful of stepping stones away" vs. a
do=
zens/hundreds of stepping stones away"

All of those are very minor points,=
 however. Overall I like the pitch.

Here is a question I got when telling =
someone about your speech. They
pointed out that directed evolution works a=
ll the time in animal breeding
(think chihuahuas and great danes vs. their =
ancestors). Experimental
biologists also often find that animals can be bre=
d in all sorts of
directions. A prof at MSU who does that recently told a r=
oom of people that
"we can basically get the animals to vary on any dimensi=
on we focus on."
That seems to contradict the argument that goal-oriented s=
election will
never work. 

I can think of rebuttals to this argument (I in=
 fact gave them to the person
who raised the issue), but I would be interes=
ted to hear your take.

PS. I can't believe you were so nice to the creatio=
nist. I would have said
something like "People who deny the overwhelming an=
d obvious evidence for
evolution have not reviewed the evidence with a rati=
onal, open mind. They
have simply come to the wrong conclusion, because the=
y are intentionally
misleading themselves or because whoever controls their=
 access to
information is misleading them."  That sounds less nice, but I d=
on't think
we should be so nice to people who are so willfully ignorant, or=
 the
converts of those who are.


PPS. You made any progress on thinking up=
 an algorithmic way to quantify
interestingess?




Best regards,
Jeff Clun=
e

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Laboratory
Corn=
ell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune

From:  Ken <kstan=
ley@...>
Reply-To:  "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>=

Date:  Thu, 24 Feb 2011 23:57:31 +0000
To:  "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@y=
ahoogroups.com>
Subject:  [neat] Online Video of Keynote Talk on "Searching=
 Without
Objectives"

>  
>  
>  
>    
> 
> I was very fortunate last year=
 to have the opportunity to deliver a keynote
> talk to the SPLASH conferen=
ce about a number of issues of interest to NEAT
> Users, including novelty =
search and Picbreeder (both of which run with NEAT),
> and I took that oppo=
rtunity to try to connect these ideas to larger issues of
> innovation and =
human discovery, and misconceptions that we tend to have about
> search in =
general.  Also fortunately, the video was recorded and just appeared
> onli=
ne at InfoQ, complete with slides shown in parallel in the same window:
> 
=
> http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Searching-Without-Objectives
> 
> I ho=
pe some of you will find the talk interesting; it gave me a chance to
> con=
nect a lot of different topics that normally don't go together in
> publica=
tions, so it provides a kind of unique perspective on some of the
> researc=
h surrounding NEAT from the last few years.  Hopefully it will show how
> s=
ome seemingly unconnected projects are actually closely related conceptuall=
y.
> 
> Of course, I am happy to hear your thoughts,
> 
> ken
> 
> PS Depen=
ding on your screen size, you may want to choose the "horizontal"
> viewing=
 option in the gray bar in the upper part of the screen to be able to
> see=
 video and slides at the same time more easily.
> 
>  
>    
> 
>  



--B_3382193710_13416011

IBUTION_BLOCKQUOTE" style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: #b5c4df 5 solid; PADDING:0 0 0 5;=
 MARGIN:0 0 0 5;"><div><div style=3D"background-color: #fff;"><span style=
=3D"display:none"> </span>

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
      
      
 =
     <p>I was very fortunate last year to have the opportunity to deliver a=
 keynote talk to the SPLASH conference about a number of issues of interest=
 to NEAT Users, including novelty search and Picbreeder (both of which run =
with NEAT), and I took that opportunity to try to connect these ideas to la=
rger issues of innovation and human discovery, and misconceptions that we t=
end to have about search in general.  Also fortunately, the video was recor=
ded and just appeared online at InfoQ, complete with slides shown in parall=
el in the same window:<br><br><a href=3D"http://www.infoq.com/presentations=
/Searching-Without-Objectives">http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Searching=
-Without-Objectives</a><br><br>
I hope some of you will find the talk inter=
esting; it gave me a chance to connect a lot of different topics that norma=
lly don't go together in publications, so it provides a kind of unique pers=
pective on some of the research surrounding NEAT from the last few years.  =
Hopefully it will show how some seemingly unconnected projects are actually=
 closely related conceptually.  <br><br>
Of course, I am happy to hear your=
 thoughts,<br><br>
ken<br><br>
PS Depending on your screen size, you may wa=
nt to choose the "horizontal" viewing option in the gray bar in the upper p=
art of the screen to be able to see video and slides at the same time more =
easily.<br><br></p>

    </div>
     

    </div></div><!-- end group email=
 --></blockquote></span></body></html>

--B_3382193710_13416011--
